question: [File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: compute_num_key_ids()] [Missing Key IDs - High] Lines 1206-1212 return 0 for missing signer key_ids with error log - can this silently undercount and allow threshold bypass?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: compute_num_key_ids()] [Integer Conversion - High] Lines 1214-1216 convert sum from usize to u32 - can overflow or truncation occur with large key counts?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: compute_num_key_ids()] [Zero Return Silent Failure - High] Returning 0 on error makes it indistinguishable from legitimate 0 key_ids - can this cause incorrect threshold calculations?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: move_to()] [State Validation - High] Line 1230 calls can_move_to before state change - but if can_move_to has side effects, can this cause issues?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: can_move_to()] [State Transition Validation - Critical] Lines 1235-1273 define valid state transitions - are all invalid transitions properly blocked?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: can_move_to()] [Idle Transition - High] Line 1238 allows any state to move to Idle - can this be abused to reset coordinator mid-operation?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: can_move_to()] [DKG State Transitions - Medium] Lines 1239-1248 enforce DKG state ordering - but can race conditions cause state to be checked differently in concurrent scenarios?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: can_move_to()] [Signing State Transitions - Medium] Lines 1249-1264 allow NonceRequest from multiple states including SigShareGather - can this enable retry attack where failed signature attempts retry indefinitely?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: can_move_to()] [Signature Type Consistency - High] State transitions check signature_type equality (lines 1250-1263) - can signature_type be changed mid-signing to bypass checks?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: new()] [Default Initialization - Medium] Lines 1279-1306 initialize coordinator with defaults - are all default values safe?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: new()] [Aggregator Initialization - High] Line 1281 creates new Aggregator - are num_keys and threshold validated before passing to aggregator?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: load()] [State Restoration - High] Lines 1309-1336 restore coordinator from SavedState - can malicious or corrupted state cause security issues?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: load()] [Aggregator Reconstruction - Medium] Line 1311 reconstructs aggregator with possibly stale threshold - can this cause mismatch with actual protocol state?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: save()] [State Serialization - Low] Lines 1339-1365 save coordinator state - are sensitive fields like private keys excluded?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: set_key_and_party_polynomials()] [Key Validation - Critical] Lines 1389-1392 compute key from polynomials and compare to provided key - but what if comparison has timing leak?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: set_key_and_party_polynomials()] [Duplicate Detection - High] Lines 1398-1402 detect duplicate party_ids by comparing HashMap size - is this sufficient or can hash collisions cause issues?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: set_key_and_party_polynomials()] [Polynomial Validation - Critical] No validation of polynomial commitments or Schnorr ID proofs - can malicious polynomials be injected via this function?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: start_dkg_round()] [DKG ID Management - Medium] Lines 1430-1434 either use provided dkg_id or increment - can wrapping_add cause ID collision?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: start_dkg_round()] [State Check - Low] No check that coordinator is in Idle state before starting DKG - should this be enforced?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: process()] [Timeout Priority - High] Lines 1448-1451 process timeout before message - can attacker trigger timeout to prevent message processing?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: process()] [Stale Packet Handling - Medium] Lines 1448-1451 drop packet if timeout fires - but is packet validated before drop, can this enable DoS?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: start_signing_round()] [Missing DKG Check - Critical] Lines 1464-1466 check for aggregate_public_key but not party_polynomials - can signing proceed with incomplete DKG state?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: start_signing_round()] [Sign ID Management - Medium] Lines 1468-1472 manage sign_id with wrapping_add - same collision risk as dkg_id?
[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: start_signing_round()] [Message Storage - Low] Line 1467 stores message - is there a size limit to prevent memory exhaustion?

[File: src/state_machine/coordinator/fire.rs] [Function: reset()] [Incomplete Reset - High] Lines 1479-1490 reset some fields but not malicious_signer_ids or malicious_dkg_signer_ids - can malicious signer tracking persist incorrectly?
